As a presidential candidate, Barack Obama was criticized for saying he admired some things about Ronald Reagan.
Last night, the president followed Mr. Reagan's example.
In a speech to Congress, Mr. Obama continued Reagan's tradition of salting the gallery with heroes from everyday life.
And in the face of economic disaster, the new president put on a cheerful disposition.
He said the massive economic stimulus which he signed last week is vital in order to save and create jobs and called for fiscal discipline on the part of Congress.
NPR's Don Gonyea reports.
It began as it always does, when the president travels to the Capitol to address the Congress.

I know that for many Americans watching right now, the state of our economy is a concern that rises above all others, and rightly so.
If you haven't been personally affected by this recession, you probably know someone who has.
He went through a litany - lost jobs, delayed retirements, businesses hanging by a thread, students accepted to college with no way to pay for it.
What is required now is for this country to pull together, confront boldly the challenges we face, and take responsibility for our future once more.

The president spoke of how the country got in the trouble it's in today, a focus on the short-term, surpluses used to enrich the wealthy rather than invested, regulations gutted in the name of profits, people buying homes they couldn't afford, banks pushing bad loans.
Well, that day of reckoning has arrived and the time to take charge of our future is here.
The president then shifted gears, looking at what now needs to be done.
He praised the Congress for passing the economic stimulus bill.
He said people will feel the benefits of its tax cuts starting in April.
He spoke of the lack of confidence people have in the financial sector.
He stressed that money in banks is insured and secure, but he also said banks need help so they can resume lending money.
So I know how unpopular it is to be seen as helping banks right now, especially when everyone is suffering in part from their bad decisions.
I promise you, I get it.
And he pledged that federal funds will be aggressively monitored.
But I also know that in a time of crisis, we cannot afford to govern out of anger or yield to the politics of the moment.
My job, our job, is to solve the problem.
Our job is to govern with a sense of responsibility.
I will not send - I will not spend a single penny for the purpose of rewarding a single Wall Street executive.
